       <div id="aws-nav-flyout-3-doc-enterprise" class="aws-nav-flyout-content" data-da="ignore-standard-impression">

         <h6> Enterprise Applications</h6> 
         <div class="aws-link"> 
          <a href="https://aws.amazon.com/documentation/workspaces/?icmpid=docs_menu">Amazon WorkSpaces</a>

           </div>

             </div> 
             <div class="aws-link"> 
              <a href="https://aws.amazon.com/documentation/config/?icmpid=docs_menu">AWS Config</a> 
             </div> 
             <div class="aws-link"> 
              <a href="https://aws.amazon.com/documentation/opsworks/?icmpid=docs_menu">AWS OpsWorks</a> 
             </div> 
             <div class="aws-link"> 
              <a href="https://aws.amazon.com/documentation/servicecatalog/?icmpid=docs_menu">AWS Service Catalog</a> 
             </div> 
            </div> 
           </div> 
           <div class="aws-link aws-parent"> 
            <a href="javascript:void(0)">Security &amp; Identity</a> 
            <div class="aws-nav-mobile-menu-group"> 
             <div class="aws-link"> 
              <a href="https://aws.amazon.com/documentation/iam/?icmpid=docs_menu">AWS Identity and Access Management (IAM)</a> 
             </div> 
             <div class="aws-link"> 
              <a href="https://aws.amazon.com/documentation/acm/?icmpid=docs_menu">AWS Certificate Manager</a>

             <div class="aws-link"> 
              <a href="https://aws.amazon.com/documentation/cloudhsm/?icmpid=docs_menu">AWS CloudHSM</a> 
             </div> 
             <div class="aws-link"> 
              <a href="https://aws.amazon.com/documentation/inspector/?icmpid=docs_menu">Amazon Inspector</a> 
             </div> 
             <div class="aws-link"> 
              <a href="https://aws.amazon.com/documentation/directory-service/?icmpid=docs_menu">AWS Directory Service</a> 
             </div> 
             <div class="aws-link">

             <div class="aws-link">

           </div>

             <div class="sidebar-cta "> 
              <p>Get Started for Free</p>

    <div class="nine columns content-with-nav"> 
     <main role="main"> 
      <section> 
       <div class="title-wrapper"> 
        <div class="row title  "> 
         <div class="twelve columns"> 
          <h1 class="" id="Amazon_EC2_Service_Level_Agreement"> <a name="Amazon_EC2_Service_Level_Agreement"> Amazon EC2 Service Level Agreement </a> </h1> 
         </div> 
        </div> 
       </div> 
       <div class="content parsys"> 
        <div class="aws-text-box section"> 
         <div class="  "> 
          <p></p>
          <section> 
           <div class="content parsys"> 
            <div class="title section row"> 
             <div class="twelve columns"> 
              <h3 id="Effective_Date:_June_1,_2013"> <a name="Effective_Date:_June_1,_2013"> Last Updated June 1, 2013 </a> </h3> 
             </div> 
            </div> 
            <div class="text section"> 
             <p>This Amazon EC2 Service Level Agreement (“SLA”) is a policy governing the use of Amazon Elastic Compute Cloud (“Amazon EC2”) and Amazon Elastic Block Store (“Amazon EBS”) under the terms of the Amazon Web Services Customer Agreement (the “AWS Agreement”) between Amazon Web Services, Inc. and its affiliates (“AWS”, “us” or “we”) and users of AWS’ services (“you”). This SLA applies separately to each account using Amazon EC2 or Amazon EBS. Unless otherwise provided herein, this SLA is subject to the terms of the AWS Agreement and capitalized terms will have the meaning specified in the AWS Agreement. We reserve the right to change the terms of this SLA in accordance with the AWS Agreement.</p> 
            </div> 
            <div class="title section row"> 
             <div class="twelve columns"> 
              <h3 id="Service_Commitment"> <a name="Service_Commitment"> Service Commitment </a> </h3> 
             </div> 
            </div> 
            <div class="text section"> 
             <p>AWS will use commercially reasonable efforts to make Amazon EC2 and Amazon EBS each available with a Monthly Uptime Percentage (defined below) of at least 99.95%, in each case during any monthly billing cycle (the “Service Commitment”). In the event Amazon EC2 or Amazon EBS does not meet the Service Commitment, you will be eligible to receive a Service Credit as described below.</p> 
            </div> 
            <div class="title section row"> 
             <div class="twelve columns"> 
              <h3 id="Definitions"> <a name="Definitions"> Definitions </a> </h3> 
             </div> 
            </div> 
            <div class="text section"> 
             <ul> 
              <li>“Monthly Uptime Percentage” is calculated by subtracting from 100% the percentage of minutes during the month in which Amazon EC2 or Amazon EBS, as applicable, was in the state of “Region Unavailable.” Monthly Uptime Percentage measurements exclude downtime resulting directly or indirectly from any Amazon EC2 SLA Exclusion (defined below).</li> 
              <li>“Region Unavailable” and “Region Unavailability” mean that more than one Availability Zone in which you are running an instance, within the same Region, is “Unavailable” to you.</li> 
              <li>“Unavailable” and “Unavailability” mean: 
               <ul> 
                <li>For Amazon EC2, when all of your running instances have no external connectivity.</li> 
                <li>For Amazon EBS, when all of your attached volumes perform zero read write IO, with pending IO in the queue.</li> 
               </ul> </li> 
              <li>A “Service Credit” is a dollar credit, calculated as set forth below, that we may credit back to an eligible account.<br /> </li> 
             </ul> 
            </div> 
            <div class="title section row"> 
             <div class="twelve columns"> 
              <h3 id="Service_Commitments_and_Service_Credits"> <a name="Service_Commitments_and_Service_Credits"> Service Commitments and Service Credits </a> </h3> 
             </div> 
            </div> 
            <div class="text section"> 
             <p>Service Credits are calculated as a percentage of the total charges paid by you (excluding one-time payments such as upfront payments made for Reserved Instances) for either Amazon EC2 or Amazon EBS (whichever was Unavailable, or both if both were Unavailable) in the Region affected for the monthly billing cycle in which the Region Unavailability occurred in accordance with the schedule below.<br /> </p> 
            </div> 
            <div class="aws-table section"> 
             <table width="502" height="62" cellspacing="0" cellpadding="1" border="0" jcr:primarytype="nt:unstructured"> 
              <tbody> 
               <tr> 
                <th style="text-align: left;"><b>Monthly Uptime Percentage</b><br /> </th> 
                <th><b>Service Credit Percentage</b></th> 
               </tr> 
               <tr> 
                <td>Less than 99.95% but equal to or greater than 99.0%</td> 
                <td>10%</td> 
               </tr> 
               <tr> 
                <td>Less than 99.0%</td> 
                <td>30%</td> 
               </tr> 
              </tbody> 
             </table> 
            </div> 
            <div class="text section"> 
             <p>We will apply any Service Credits only against future Amazon EC2 or Amazon EBS payments otherwise due from you. At our discretion, we may issue the Service Credit to the credit card you used to pay for the billing cycle in which the Unavailability occurred. Service Credits will not entitle you to any refund or other payment from AWS. A Service Credit will be applicable and issued only if the credit amount for the applicable monthly billing cycle is greater than one dollar ($1 USD). Service Credits may not be transferred or applied to any other account. Unless otherwise provided in the AWS Agreement, your sole and exclusive remedy for any unavailability, non-performance, or other failure by us to provide Amazon EC2 or Amazon EBS is the receipt of a Service Credit (if eligible) in accordance with the terms of this SLA.<br /> </p> 
            </div> 
            <div class="title section row"> 
             <div class="twelve columns"> 
              <h3 id="Credit_Request_and_Payment_Procedures"> <a name="Credit_Request_and_Payment_Procedures"> Credit Request and Payment Procedures </a> </h3> 
             </div> 
            </div> 
            <div class="text section"> 
             <p>To receive a Service Credit, you must submit a claim by <a href="https://aws.amazon.com/support/createCase?type=account_billing" adhocenable="false" onclick="s_objectID=&quot;https://aws.amazon.com/support/createCase?type=account_billing_1&quot;;return this.s_oc?this.s_oc(e):true">opening a case in the AWS Support Center</a>. To be eligible, the credit request must be received by us by the end of the second billing cycle after which the incident occurred and must include:</p> 
             <ol> 
              <li>the words “SLA Credit Request” in the subject line;</li> 
              <li>the dates and times of each Unavailability incident that you are claiming;</li> 
              <li>the affected EC2 instance IDs or the affected EBS volume IDs; and</li> 
              <li>your request logs that document the errors and corroborate your claimed outage (any confidential or sensitive information in these logs should be removed or replaced with asterisks).<br /> </li> 
             </ol> 
             <p>If the Monthly Uptime Percentage of such request is confirmed by us and is less than the Service Commitment, then we will issue the Service Credit to you within one billing cycle following the month in which your request is confirmed by us. Your failure to provide the request and other information as required above will disqualify you from receiving a Service Credit.<br /> </p> 
            </div> 
            <div class="title section row"> 
             <div class="twelve columns"> 
              <h3 id="Amazon_EC2_SLA_Exclusions"> <a name="Amazon_EC2_SLA_Exclusions"> Amazon EC2 SLA Exclusions </a> </h3> 
             </div> 
            </div> 
            <div class="text section"> 
             <p>The Service Commitment does not apply to any unavailability, suspension or termination of Amazon EC2 or Amazon EBS, or any other Amazon EC2 or Amazon EBS performance issues: (i) that result from a suspension described in Section 6.1 of the AWS Agreement; (ii) caused by factors outside of our reasonable control, including any force majeure event or Internet access or related problems beyond the demarcation point of Amazon EC2 or Amazon EBS; (iii) that result from any actions or inactions of you or any third party, including failure to acknowledge a recovery volume; (iv) that result from your equipment, software or other technology and/or third party equipment, software or other technology (other than third party equipment within our direct control); (v) that result from failures of individual instances or volumes not attributable to Region Unavailability; (vi) that result from any maintenance as provided for pursuant to the AWS Agreement; or (vii) arising from our suspension and termination of your right to use Amazon EC2 or Amazon EBS in accordance with the AWS Agreement (collectively, the “Amazon EC2 SLA Exclusions”). If availability is impacted by factors other than those used in our Monthly Uptime Percentage calculation, then we may issue a Service Credit considering such factors at our discretion.<br /> </p> 
            </div> 
            <div class="aws-text-box section"> 
             <div class=" "> 
              <p><a href="https://aws.amazon.com/ec2/sla/historical">Prior Version(s)</a></p> 
              <p></p> 
             </div> 
            </div> 
           </div> 
          </section>
          <br /> 
          <p></p> 
         </div> 
        </div> 
       </div> 
      </section> 
     </main> 
    </div> 
   </div> 
  </div>

      <a href="https://portal.aws.amazon.com/gp/aws/developer/registration/index.html?nc2=h_ct" class="aws-page-footer-cta-button">Create a Free Account</a> 
     </div> 
    </div>

      <li><a href="https://www.facebook.com/amazonwebservices?nc1=f_so_fb"><i class="icon-facebook"></i> &nbsp;AWS on Facebook</a></li> 
      <li><a href="https://plus.google.com/+amazonwebservices?nc1=f_so_go"><i class="icon-google-plus"></i> &nbsp;AWS on Google+</a></li> 
      <li><a href="https://aws.amazon.com/blogs/aws/?nc1=f_so_bl"><i class="icon-list-alt"></i> &nbsp;AWS Blog</a></li> 
      <li><a href="http://aws.amazon.com/rss/whats-new.rss?nc1=f_so_rs"><i class="icon-rss"></i> &nbsp;What's New? RSS</a></li> 
     </ul> 
    </div> 
   </div>

    <div class="aws-mid-8 aws-col aws-page-footer-right-item"> 
     <div class="aws-text-box section"> 
      <div class="  "> 
       <p><b>Amazon Web Services is Hiring.</b></p> 
       <p>Amazon Web Services (AWS) is a dynamic, growing business unit within Amazon.com. We are currently hiring Software Development Engineers, Product Managers, Account Managers, Solutions Architects, Support Engineers, System Engineers, Designers and more. Visit our <a href="https://aws.amazon.com/careers/?nc1=f_hi">Careers</a> page or our <a href="https://aws.amazon.com/careers/sde/?nc1=f_hi">Developer-specific Careers</a> page to learn more.</p> 
       <p></p> 
       <p class="p1">Amazon Web Services is an Equal Opportunity Employer.</p> 
       <p></p> 
       <p></p>
